section.title: Purpose
section.para: When setting up new hosts, there are a number of configuration or other settings to be made. They are used to specify their hardware configuration, to determine what OS they should boot and to fine-tune the behavior of applications running on them. All the necessary steps for the desired configuration of the nodes can be done manually and also be changed later through the various dialogs from the main window.

As a convenient alternative, the Hardware Wizard guides you through the necessary configuration steps with a special emphasis on the hardware configuration. It uses the auto-detected hardware properties of hosts to suggest their optimal configuration options. Furthermore, it tries to keep a balance between the available configuration strategies: Using templates, property/config sets or individual properties/config classes.

section.title: Selecting Hosts
section.para:
Selecting hosts for configuration
Selecting hosts for configuration
The first step is to select the hosts that should be configured . Initially, the lists of hosts is empty. One or more of the four buttons at the bottom have to be pressed to pre-select hosts that should be considered. The Unconfigured button adds all hosts that do not have any hardware configured at all. A freshly added host without an assigned Host Template will fall into this category. The Partially Configured button adds hosts that already have some hardware configured correctly but not all of it. The Wrongly Configured button adds hosts, where the configured hardware properties do not match the hardware detected at boot, e.g. when nodes have been updated with more ram. Finally, the Selected button adds hosts, that have been selected in the enclosure view, including hosts that are configured correctly already.

Once one or more of the buttons are pressed, the affected hosts will show up in the table. To keep things compact, hosts with identically detected hardware are grouped together and shown in hostlist syntax. By default, all shown groups are selected and will be configured using a single Host Template and therefore single Hardware Property, Generic Property and Config Set. The possible differences in hardware configurations within the list of selected hosts will be handled by the wizard with the per host settings. In case all the groups shouldn't use the same Host Template, groups may be selected or deselected individually and the remaining ones can be configured by running the wizard again later. Groups of hosts with identical hardware can't be split up though. If this is required, select the hosts individually in the Enclosure View and use only the Selected button. Once the desired groups of hosts have been selected click Next to continue configuring them.

section.title: Configure Host Template
section.para:
The main configuration of hosts comes from the Host Template. This determines what Hardware Property Set, Generic Property Set and Config Set is used for each host. The wizard tries to find an existing Host Template that matches the hardware detected for at least some of the selected hosts. If it does this Host Template will be pre selected and the "Use existing Host Template" choice will be active.
The resulting configuration, if left unaltered, is shown below in tree form. The Hardware Properties in the Hardware Property Set for the Host Template are color coded to show how well they fit the groups of hosts being configured. Hovering over a Hardware property brings up a helpful tool-tip explaining the coloring.
A green bulb means that the property matches the detected value for all hosts. A yellow bulb means that is matches some hosts but not all of them. This happens when hosts have different hardware and is acceptable. A red bulb means that the value matches none of the hosts and is a bad fit. The property value should be changed in the follow up pages or a different Host Template should be selected.

The pre selected Host Template might not be the desired choice and a different one can be selected from the drop-down menu. The choices are colored showing how well a Host Template matches the hosts.
Here a green bulb means that the Host Template matches the detected hardware of at least one host perfectly. A yellow bulb means that not all hardware for the hosts is configured but at least nothing is configured wrong. A red bulb means the Host Template includes a hardware property that matches none of the hosts and would be a bad fit. None the less it can be the right choice and it can be modified to fit in the followup page or the correct hardware properties can be set on a per host basis by the wizard.

If none of the existing Host Templates are suitable then a new Host Template can be created in one of two ways. An existing Host Template can be cloned or a completely new Host Template can be created.
In both cases a name for the new Host Template must be given. The difference in the 2 choices is that clone will pre select the Hardware Property Set, Generic Property Set and Config Set of the existing Host Template for use in the new one.

section.title: Select Hardware Property Set
section.para:
This page selects the Hardware Property Set used in the selected Host Template and is the main source for hardware configuration. Like in the previous page an existing Hardware Property Set can be used, can be cloned or a new Hardware Property Set can be created. Most likely an existing Hardware Property Set will be pre selected. A different existing Hardware Property Set can be selected from the drop-down menu and again the choices are color coded for how well they fit the hosts.
Changing the Hardware Property Set affects the selected Host Template. If an existing Host Template was chosen in the last page then changing it might affect hosts other than the ones being configured in the wizard. In such a case the wizard will ask for confirmation that that is desired.
The existing Hardware Property Set can be replaced with the auto-detected Hardware Properties on the bottom right for a better fit. If multiple groups of hosts are being configured at the same time the properties where hosts differ will have a drop-down menu to select the most suitable value.
Once the right selection is made the properties can be copied over the existing Hardware Property Set by clicking the << button. The wizard will ask for confirmation if this impacts hosts not currently being configured and then set the Hardware Property Set on the bottom left into edit mode, same as it is when cloning or creating a new Hardware Property Set.
The difference between cloning an existing Hardware Property Set and creating a new one is just what Hardware Properties are pre selected. Cloning will start with the properties the cloned set has while creating a new one start with a blank slate.
In all 3 cases the Hardware Property Set can be further edited by selecting different values for properties, adding properties or removing properties.
Once the right Hardware Properties are selected click Next to continue.

section.title: Resolve Hardware Conflict
section.para:
If more than one group of hosts is being configured at the same time or when the selected Hardware Property Set is insufficient to correctly configure the hosts then the Resolve Hardware Conflict page comes next. At the bottom the conflicting or missing hardware properties are listed showing the correct value for each group. If only one property is missing then the wizard will suggest to add the property individually per host.
On the other hand if multiple properties are missing adding a Hardware Property Set per host might be a better way and will be pre selected.
Which option is chosen is a matter of taste and there is no wrong choice here. One can also choose "configure manually later" to tell the wizard to ignore the conflict. Note that this will result in hosts that are only partially or wrongly configured which will need to be corrected later.

section.title: Additional per Host Hardware Property Set
section.para: If per host Hardware Property Sets was chosen in the previous page then the set to be used for each group will be picked here. The Wizard will look for an existing Hardware Property Set for each group that contains the right Hardware Properties already. If one is found it will be pre selected. Otherwise a name for a new set must be entered before one can continue.

section.title: Select Generic Property Set / Select Config Set
section.para:
To complete the Host Template a Generic Property Set and Config Set must be selected. The two pages are very much alike and similar to selecting the Hardware Property Set. Again there are 3 main options: Use existing set, clone existing set and new empty set. Since there is no auto-detection for the values in each set there is no color coding of the choices.
An existing set can not be modified in the current version but when clone existing set or new empty set is chosen then properties and configs can be added to or removed from the set.
In the Select Generic Property Set page if the hosts have IPMI then the IPMI properties deserve consideration. In the Select Config Set page the Boot Config, Disk Config and UnionFS Chroot configs are usually set.

section.title: Summary
section.para: This is the last page of the wizard and the final confirmation of all the choices made before the data is actually stored in the database. At the top the common configuration for all host from the Host Template is shown in tree form. At the bottom the additional Hardware Properties or Hardware Property Sets that will be set for each group of hosts on a per host basis to override the host template is shown. Host groups with no per host overrides are not shown.

If an existing Host Template or existing Hardware Property Set was modified then this is the last chance to not save that change. By clicking Finish all the modifications are made and the configuration is assigned to all hosts. The hosts should then be fully configured and ready to boot.
